CreditLine: Promised gift of John and Berthe Ford
Description: Palden Lhamo is a female protector deity (especially of the Dalai Lamas) who accompanies the protector-deity Mahakala. She is frequently depicted alone, riding a mule, as in this thanka, where due to the gold-on-black medium she is an elusive presence. Her Sanskrit name is Shridevi ("auspicious goddess"), suggesting a relationship to the Hindu goddess of destruction, Kali. In this painting, she is accompanied by many ferocious attendants, each identified in tiny gold letters. The mountains and trees are those near a lake in Tibet where Palden Lhamo manifests herself.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection
Exhibitions.Textblock: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Santa Barbara Museum of Art, Santa Barbara; Albuquerque Museum, Albuquerque; Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham. 2001-2003.

Provenance: Stuart Perrin, New York [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; John and Berthe Ford, Baltimore, March 25, 1984, by purchase.
Title: Protector Deity Palden Lhamo with Entourage
